== How is GNOME translated upstream ==

The localization of upstream GNOME applications and documentation is described and coordinated from the <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/|GNOME Translation Project]]</nowiki> (GTP).

<nowiki>[[File:GNOME-l10n.png|The GNOME localization statistics|width=500]]</nowiki>

There you will find resources and information on how to translate GNOME, how to join a translation team, translations statistics and much more. In addition, the <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/MailingList|GNOME i18n mailing list]]</nowiki> is used for general coordination of the GNOME internationalization and localization effort.

GNOME does not use a web translation frontend for their translations. Instead, translations (PO files, xml and docbook files, etc.) are made directly available at the <nowiki>[[http://l10n.gnome.org/|GNOME statistics site]]</nowiki>. Depending on the particular version you want to translate, you'll have to choose the right link where to get the files from.

Important links:

* <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/|GNOME Translation Project]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[http://l10n.gnome.org/|GNOME Translation Statistics]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/MailingList|GNOME i18n mailing list]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/LocalisationGuide|GNOME Localisation Guide]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[http://l10n.gnome.org/teams/|List of GNOME translation teams]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/Schedule|GNOME release schedules]]</nowiki>

== How to get in touch or join a GNOME translation team ==

If you are interested in both translating Ubuntu and cooperating with upstream translations, we encourage to join or get in touch with your local GNOME translation team in addition to your Ubuntu translation team.

You simply have to go to the <nowiki>[[http://l10n.gnome.org/teams/|list of GNOME translation teams]]</nowiki>, find your team in the list and follow the instructions on how to join or contact them. If you cannot find a team for your language in the list, it might be a good opportunity to <nowiki>[[mailto:gnome-i18n@gnome.org|request the creation of one]]</nowiki>.

In addition, you can also subscribe to the general <nowiki>[[http://live.gnome.org/TranslationProject/MailingList|GNOME i18n mailing list]]</nowiki> to be kept up to date with the latest developments and announcements in the GNOME translations world.

== How to contribute translations back to upstream ==

The general workflow for contributing translations back to upstream is the following

# <nowiki>[[..-..-KnowledgeBase-Exporting|Download the translation from Launchpad]]</nowiki>
# <nowiki>[[#GnomeUbuntuMapping|Locate where the upstream translation is]]</nowiki>
# <nowiki>[[..-..-KnowledgeBase-LaunchpadTranslationsAdaptToUpstream|Adapt the Launchpad translation to the upstream translation]]</nowiki>
# <nowiki>[[#GnomeSubmittingUpstream|Submit the translation upstream]]</nowiki>

=== Locating the upstream translations: mapping of Ubuntu/GNOME modules and versions ===

If you'd like to send the translations you've done in Launchpad back to the GNOME project, the following lists will help you determine where to send those translations depending on the Ubuntu version you've been translating:

* <nowiki>[[GnomeLucidModules]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[GnomeKarmicModules]]</nowiki>
* <nowiki>[[GnomeJauntyModules]]</nowiki>

=== Submitting translations to GNOME ===

You've got several options for this:

# Contact the <nowiki>[[http://l10n.gnome.org/teams/|GNOME translation team for your particular language]]</nowiki> and send them the translation(s). This is generally the easiest way
# Report a bug to <nowiki>[[https://bugzilla.gnome.org/|GNOME's Bugzilla]]</nowiki> and attach the translation(s) as a patch. You will need to register an account there first.
